summary: Great Britain's Greg Rutherford is through to the long jump final at the World Championships in Beijing.
The Treasury has announced that it is raising the rate at which it charges the UK's five biggest banks with the so-called bank levy.
A US appeals court has ruled that the National Security Agency's collection of US phone records is unconstitutional.
Newcastle returned to the top of the Championship with victory over struggling Aston Villa at St James' Park.
The humble coconut is a tropical staple in many parts of the world.

Is the Organisation of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) finally getting its act together? For Opec, the trouble was that Saudi Arabia was unwilling to curb production without Iran doing likewise, a position also underpinned by the longstanding geopolitical tension between the two countries which are the leading powers in the Gulf.
An Irish man has been shot dead while on holiday with his family in Spain.
Blackburn Rovers have signed Aston Villa midfielder Joe Mason and Chelsea defender Josh Houghton on season-long loan deals.
The US Treasury Department has accused the European Commission of targeting US companies in its probe into Apple's tax affairs.
Footballer Robert Snodgrass has appeared in court charged with dangerous driving.
David Cameron and the chancellor have both said they would not cut the top rate of income tax to 40p.
A new home for rugby's Hall of Fame has been officially opened.
The contract to build the trains for the HS2 high-speed rail line has been launched.
It's the Monaco Grand Prix and Eddie Jordan is in the pits.
The Australian government is giving kids the chance to design a new national park.
As the 70th anniversary of the evacuation of Dunkirk is marked, BBC News looks at the experiences of those who were involved.
A tiny piece of Viking treasure discovered in a field has been valued by experts on the BBC's Antiques Roadshow.
Ipswich Town have signed Wales Under-19 midfielder George James on a three-year deal from Cardiff City.

Roger Goodell's annual state-of-the-league address to the National Football League's club owners on Thursday will be a chance for the league's bosses to once again defend their beleaguered commissioner.
One of the world's largest Roman mosaics will go to a new museum, the city's mayor has said.
An investigation into the crash of Virgin Galactic's space tourism craft has found that a safety device failed.
The administrators of Bradford Bulls have delayed a decision on the sale of the club until next week.
The mother of a schoolgirl murdered by a convicted killer has said her family's faith in the UK's ability to protect citizens has been "destroyed".
A mother accused of killing her two-year-old son by leaving him in a bath has told a court she was "stupid" not to go upstairs.
Atletico Madrid forward Antoine Griezmann will miss Saturday's derby against Real Madrid because of a foot injury.
A group of Silicon Valley heavyweights has pledged $1bn (£700m) to fund research into artificial intelligence.
Thailand's Crown Prince Maha Vajiralongkorn is set to become the country's new king.
